title: Why isn't there an AD equivalent of Morellonomicon yet?
body:
Ever since Executioner's Calling was removed, there is no way to counter sustain monsters without ignite. If you were AP, you can just buy {{item:3165}}, but if you're AD and you're fighting {{champion:50}} {{champion:9}} or {{champion:36}} or for some reason AP {{champion:5}} then you need to have ignite or someone else who is AP with Morellonomicon.

Not saying we need executioner's calling back, because it was pretty bad, but it would be pretty handy to get another grievous wounds item for AD champions.

I think this is sort of the wrong direction: we don't need more Grievous Wounds in the game, we need sustain that can be dealt with organically, i.e. without having to resort to a mechanic that hard-counters healing. A lot of overbearing healing in the game ({{champion:36}} and {{champion:50}} 's ultimates, namely) is only allowed to be as strong as it is now because it's expected to work against GW, and if it were healthy on its own, we wouldn't need the mechanic. {{champion:16}} is proof that we can have crazy healing in the game and still have interesting and interactive gameplay, so with appropriate tweaks to less individually counterable sustain we wouldn't even need Grievous Wounds at all.

> [{quoted}](name=Nilok,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=sojnwVYf,comment-id=000a0001,timestamp=2015-04-09T02:34:23.355+0000)

It's true that there are less Grievous Wounds in the game, and I think that's a good thing. Ideally, the mechanic should be phased out completely, since it counters healing in a manner that is both excessively harsh and low on gameplay. I think the gameplay behind healing should be "this champion is healing for a lot right now, I should outplay that in this fight", and not "this champion has a lot of healing, I should cut that in half for the rest of the game". Because Mundo or Swain-like healing doesn't really allow for strategy 1 (there's no real way of outplaying their healing on a play-by-play basis), the default so far has been strategy 2, and I think that's something that needs to be fixed.

To be fair, you can wait out Mundo's ult. Or bait it out and disengage, it's not like he has hard CC. Or dogpile him if your team is communicating well, so he goes down before he can ult. That's a form of outplay.
If you repeatedly bait out Swain's ult, you'll eventually find yourself with an 8 second window immediately after he just toggled it off. Alternatively, he'll run out of mana eventually -- though getting a good Swain to go oom is much harder. Playing around that cooldown is another form of outplay.

They aren't _flashy_ or **LCSBIGPLAYS**, but they are forms of outplay that you can take advantage of.
That's the idea Riot had, improve healing mechanics and eventually get rid of GW.

As far as I know, Riot's still looking for a way to properly remove Grievous Wounds in their entirety. Having heals balanced around the existence of this mechanic hasn't really helped anyone, as anyone that's had to face a Mundo with only a single ignite across the whole team to deal with him would know. The problem with that is that heals would actually have to be nerfed pretty much across the board to compensate, which would throw off balance really hard. A similar situation would arise, actually, if they made Grievous Wounds *more* accessible. Thus, They're going to be treading very carefully around what they change in regards to it. Nobody actually used Executioner's Calling, so that was pretty much the one safe move they could make.

Excluding the fact that AP and AD items aren't supposed to be paralleled? Because nobody bought executioners calling.
It wasn't slot efficient enough for ADCs, Didn't give the right stats for AD mids or bruisers.
The problem with Morellonomicon is that it is stupidly cost efficient and worth getting even without considering the grievous wounds. In order to make an AD Morellonomicon worth using, you'd have to make it so good that it is worth buying even when the other team doesn't have sustain which would make sustain champions unviable.

They need to rework it anyway. 

Healing reduction in general needs better options and I don't think it should be actual items. 

A flask would make more sense.

Healing reduction should be removed from the game.  If you want to stop someone from using a healing spell, silence or stun them.  (Or knockup, charm, polymorph, fear, suppress... you get the idea.)  Why does one specific type of spell need *another* counter?  Especially one that's built into things that are strong on their own ({{summoner:14}} {{item:3165}} ) so you get it for free?

{{champion:36}} {{champion:50}} ults would probably need some nerfs, but that's better than the current binary state of "are they grievous wounded?  If yes, they're useless, if no, they're immortal".  (And with how common ignite is, well, it's no wonder how frequently they see competitive play.)

I would actually favor indirect nerfs over direct ones, e.g. longer CD for Mundo and heavier mana costs for Swain, so that their ults are still good at what they do, but the opposing team has more opportunity to engage when they're not available.  But they might have to do some direct nerf too.

Totally OK.

I hate morellonomicon, it's supposed to be a niche item yet you can build it on most mages.

The counters to high-sustain champions are to burst them down before they can heal, or to be dealing more damage than they are healing each second.

AD carries generally have very high damage output, so they can deal damage faster than a high-sustain champion can heal.  An ADC with good items can kill a Mundo or Swain through their ultimates.
Many mages have more of a poke-over-time pattern, which makes it much harder for them to deal with high-sustain champions (they just heal up between damage rotations), which is why they have more need of a healing reduction item to counter high sustain.


In any case, Grievous Wounds shouldn't be in the game, and the healing abilities should be adjusted to compensate.  It's not healthy for an extremely common summoner spell and a popular items to hard-counter champions with healing, despite the fact that the healing reduction is almost never the reason that you take that spell or buy that item.
